segments.text: A week later, Dorian Gray was sitting in the conservatory at Selby Royal. He was engaged in a quiet conversation with the elegant Duchess of Monmouth. Around them, the tea-time gathering unfolded: the Duchess presided over the service with her daintily moving white hands and full red lips, smiling at a whispered remark from Dorian. Lord Henry lounged in a silk-draped wicker chair, equally amused by the scene, while on a peach-coloured divan sat Lady Narborough, feigning interest in the duke’s description of a newly acquired Brazilian beetle. A few young men in elaborate smoking-suits passed tea-cakes among the guests, and the air was ripe with anticipation for more arrivals the next day.
What are you two talking about? I hope Dorian has told you about my plan for rechristening everything, Gladys. It is a delightful idea.

voice_traits.pacing: measured with a hint of playful mischief

segments.text: But I don’t want to be rechristened, Harry. I am quite satisfied with my own name, and I am sure Mr. Gray should be satisfied with his.

My dear Gladys, I would not alter either name for the world. They are both perfect. I was thinking chiefly of flowers. Yesterday I cut an orchid for my button-hole. It was a marvellous spotted thing, as effective as the seven deadly sins. In a thoughtless moment I asked one of the gardeners what it was called, and he told me it was a fine specimen of Robinsoniana—or something dreadful of that kind. It is a sad truth, but we have lost the faculty of giving lovely names to things. Names are everything. I never quarrel with actions. My one quarrel is with words. That is the reason I hate vulgar realism in literature. The man who could call a spade a spade should be compelled to use one. It is the only thing he is fit for.

voice_traits.pacing: deliberate and measured, allowing each thought to resonate
voice_traits.distinctive: eloquent, with a hint of irony

segments.text: Then what should we call you, Harry?
His name is Prince Paradox.

voice_traits.pauses: a slight pause for dramatic effect

segments.text: I recognize him in a flash.
I won’t hear of it. From a label there is no escape! I refuse the title.

voice_traits.pronunciation: crisp with an emphasis on key words

segments.text: Royalties may not abdicate.

voice_traits.pauses: a slight pause for dramatic effect

segments.text: You wish me to defend my throne, then?

voice_traits.pacing: deliberate with a hint of sarcasm

segments.text: Yes.
I give the truths of to-morrow.
I prefer the mistakes of to-day.

voice_traits.emotion: amused, with a touch of irony

segments.text: You disarm me, Gladys.

voice_traits.tone: warm with a tinge of admiration

segments.text: Of your shield, Harry, not of your spear.
I never tilt against beauty.
That is your error, Harry, believe me. You value beauty far too much.

voice_traits.emotion: witty with a hint of admonishment

segments.text: How can you say that? I admit that I think it is better to be beautiful than to be good. But on the other hand, no one is more ready than I am to acknowledge that it is better to be good than to be ugly.
Ugliness is one of the seven deadly sins, then? What becomes of your simile about the orchid?

voice_traits.pauses: a slight pause between the two questions

segments.text: Ugliness is one of the seven deadly virtues, Gladys. You, as a good Tory, must not underrate them. Beer, the Bible, and the seven deadly virtues have made our England what she is.

voice_traits.distinctive: rapid-fire wit with a knowing smile

segments.text: You don’t like your country, then?
I live in it.
That you may censure it the better.
Would you have me take the verdict of Europe on it?
What do they say of us?
That Tartuffe has emigrated to England and opened a shop.

voice_traits.pauses: a slight pause after the statement

segments.text: Is that yours, Harry?
I give it to you.

voice_traits.pronunciation: clear with a touch of bravado

segments.text: I could not use it. It is too true.
You need not be afraid. Our countrymen never recognize a description.

voice_traits.emotion: confident with a hint of irony

segments.text: They are practical.
They are more cunning than practical. When they make up their ledger, they balance stupidity by wealth, and vice by hypocrisy.

voice_traits.pauses: carefully timed to underline the irony

segments.text: Still, we have done great things.

voice_traits.pauses: a mindful pause after the statement

segments.text: Great things have been thrust on us, Gladys.

voice_traits.distinctive: with a hint of rueful irony

segments.text: We have carried their burden.
Only as far as the Stock Exchange.
I believe in the race.

voice_traits.pauses: a brief pause to highlight conviction

segments.text: It represents the survival of the pushing.
It has development.
Decay fascinates me more.

voice_traits.tone: softly reflective with a hint of bitterness

segments.text: What of art?

voice_traits.pauses: a slight pause after the question

segments.text: It is a malady.
Love?
An illusion.

voice_traits.pauses: a slight pause to emphasize dismissal
voice_traits.distinctive: with an air of dispassionate critique

segments.text: Religion?

voice_traits.pronunciation: clear, with a slight emphasis on 'religion'

segments.text: The fashionable substitute for belief.
You are a sceptic.
Never! Scepticism is the beginning of faith.
What are you?

voice_traits.pauses: a slight pause to register thought

segments.text: To define is to limit.

voice_traits.pauses: a thoughtful pause after the statement
voice_traits.distinctive: with an air of subtle profundity

segments.text: Give me a clue.

voice_traits.distinctive: with a hint of playful demand

segments.text: Threads snap. You would lose your way in the labyrinth.

voice_traits.pauses: a pause between the two sentences for impact

segments.text: You bewilder me. Let us talk of someone else.
Our host is a delightful topic. Years ago he was christened Prince Charming.

voice_traits.pauses: a slight pause after the opening clause

segments.text: Ah! Don’t remind me of that.
Our host is rather horrid this evening. I believe he thinks that Monmouth married me on purely scientific principles—as the best specimen he could find of a modern butterfly.

voice_traits.distinctive: with a playful yet biting wit

segments.text: Well, I hope he won’t stick pins into you, Duchess.

voice_traits.pauses: a slight pause at the beginning

segments.text: Oh! My maid does that already, Mr. Gray, when she is annoyed with me.
And what does she get annoyed with you about, Duchess?
For the most trivial things, Mr. Gray, I assure you. Usually because I come in at ten minutes to nine and tell her that I must be dressed by half-past eight.

voice_traits.pacing: deliberate with a slight mock urgency
voice_traits.distinctive: with an air of refined sarcasm

segments.text: How unreasonable of her! You should give her warning.

I daren’t, Mr. Gray. Why, she invents hats for me. You remember the one I wore at Lady Hilstone’s garden-party? You don’t, but it is nice of you to pretend that you do. Well, she made it out of nothing. All good hats are made out of nothing.

voice_traits.emotion: witty with a touch of self-mockery

segments.text: Like all good reputations, Gladys. Every effect that one produces gives one an enemy. To be popular one must be a mediocrity.

voice_traits.pauses: short pauses to underline key ideas

segments.text: Not with women, and women rule the world. I assure you we can’t bear mediocrities. We women, as someone says, love with our ears, just as you men love with your eyes, if you ever love at all.
It seems to me that we never do anything else.

voice_traits.pauses: a slight pause after the phrase

segments.text: Ah! Then, you never really love, Mr. Gray.

My dear Gladys! How can you say that? Romance lives by repetition, and repetition converts an appetite into an art. Besides, each time that one loves is the only time one has ever loved. Difference of object does not alter singleness of passion. It merely intensifies it. We can have in life but one great experience at best, and the secret of life is to reproduce that experience as often as possible.

voice_traits.emotion: convincing with an undercurrent of passion
voice_traits.pauses: strategic pauses to emphasize key insights
voice_traits.distinctive: with a cultured, almost lyrical delivery

segments.text: Even when one has been wounded by it, Harry?

voice_traits.pauses: a brief pause at the end

segments.text: Especially when one has been wounded by it.

voice_traits.emotion: sincere with a touch of melancholy

segments.text: What do you say to that, Mr. Gray?

voice_traits.pauses: a brief pause before the question

segments.text: I always agree with Harry, Duchess.
Even when he is wrong?
Harry is never wrong, Duchess.

voice_traits.pronunciation: clear with a hint of mischief

segments.text: And does his philosophy make you happy?
I have never searched for happiness. Who wants happiness? I have searched for pleasure.

voice_traits.emotion: confessional with a tinge of melancholy

segments.text: And found it, Mr. Gray?
Often. Too often.

voice_traits.emotion: wistful with a trace of melancholy
voice_traits.pauses: a slight pause between the sentences

segments.text: I am searching for peace, and if I don’t go and dress, I shall have none this evening.

voice_traits.tone: matter-of-fact with a hint of urgency

segments.text: Let me get you some orchids, Duchess.
Dorian rose to his feet, moving purposefully through the conservatory as the conversation flowed.

voice_traits.distinctive: richly descriptive with a measured cadence

segments.text: You are flirting disgracefully with him. You had better take care. He is very fascinating.

voice_traits.distinctive: with a hint of ironic advice

segments.text: If he were not, there would be no battle.
Greek meets Greek, then?
I am on the side of the Trojans. They fought for a woman.

voice_traits.pauses: a slight pause after the first sentence
voice_traits.distinctive: with a confident, almost martial rhythm

segments.text: They were defeated.
There are worse things than capture.
You gallop with a loose rein.
Pace gives life.
I shall write it in my diary tonight.
What?
That a burnt child loves the fire.
I am not even singed. My wings are untouched.
You use them for everything, except flight.
Courage has passed from men to women. It is a new experience for us.
You have a rival.

voice_traits.tone: matter-of-fact with a hint of mischief

segments.text: Who?
Lady Narborough. She perfectly adores him.

voice_traits.pauses: a slight pause before the name

segments.text: You fill me with apprehension. The appeal to antiquity is fatal to us who are romanticists.

voice_traits.emotion: a mix of concern and resolve
voice_traits.pronunciation: clear, with a slight tremor of apprehension

segments.text: Romanticists! You have all the methods of science.
Men have educated us.
But not explained you.
Describe us as a sex.

voice_traits.emotion: firm with a hint of provocation
voice_traits.pauses: a brief pause for dramatic effect

segments.text: Sphinxes without secrets.
How long, Mr. Gray, is! Let us go and help him. I have not yet told him the colour of my frock.

voice_traits.pauses: brief, marking the shift in topic

segments.text: Ah! You must suit your frock to his flowers, Gladys.
That would be a premature surrender.
Romantic art begins with its climax.

voice_traits.emotion: solemn, with a touch of irony

segments.text: I must keep an opportunity for retreat.

voice_traits.emotion: pragmatic with a hint of regret
voice_traits.distinctive: with an air of reserved practicality

segments.text: In the Parthian manner?
They found safety in the desert. I could not do that.

voice_traits.emotion: sincere with a touch of regret
voice_traits.pauses: a slight pause between the two sentences

segments.text: Women are not always allowed a choice.

voice_traits.pronunciation: clear, with a slight smirk in the tone
voice_traits.distinctive: with an air of gentle chiding

segments.text: Hardly had Lord Henry finished his sentence when, from the far end of the conservatory, a stifled groan broke the conversation. A heavy, dull fall echoed as everyone started up. The Duchess stood motionless in horror. With fear in his eyes, Lord Henry rushed through the flapping palms to find Dorian Gray lying face down on the tiled floor in a deathlike swoon.

voice_traits.pacing: quickening to match the sudden action

segments.text: He was carried at once into the blue drawing-room and laid upon one of the sofas. After a short time, he came to himself, looking around with a dazed expression.

voice_traits.pauses: short pauses to transition the scene

segments.text: What has happened? Oh! I remember. Am I safe here, Harry?
My dear Dorian, you merely fainted. That was all. You must have overtired yourself. You had better not come down to dinner. I will take your place.

voice_traits.tone: calm and reassuring with a clinical detachment
voice_traits.pauses: a slight pause after 'my dear Dorian,'

segments.text: No, I will come down. I would rather come down. I must not be alone.

voice_traits.pauses: a brief pause after each sentence
voice_traits.distinctive: with a fragile yet insistent quality

segments.text: Dorian went to his room and dressed. As he sat at the table, a wild recklessness of gaiety played about his manner. Yet now and then, a thrill of terror ran through him as he remembered that, pressed against the conservatory window like a white handkerchief, he had seen the face of James Vane watching him.

voice_traits.distinctive: with a quietly tragic, narrative cadence
